title: 1.2: Basic Properties
summary: Learn to update particle color and size with simple constant values
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use Update Color and Update Size blocks to change particle properties. We'll start with simple constant values - no time-based calculations yet. You'll create a complete particle system from scratch with color and size updates.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>Color4</filter-value> block and set its value to orange (R: 1, G: 0.5, B: 0, A: 1)
Connect the Color4 block's output to CreateParticle block's color input
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value to 0.3
Connect the Float block's output to CreateParticle block's size input
Add a <filter-value>BoxShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a box volume and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block to handle particle movement and connect between BoxShape and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Position</filter-value> block to get the current position and connect to UpdatePosition block
Add a <filter-value>ScaledDirection</filter-value> block to get the scaled direction
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to combine position and direction and connect Position and ScaledDirection blocks to the left and right inputs respectively
Connect the result from the math block to UpdatePosition's position input
Add an <filter-value>UpdateColor</filter-value> block after UpdatePosition block and connect between UpdatePosition and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>InitialColor</filter-value> block and connect its output to UpdateColor block's color input
Add an <filter-value>UpdateSize</filter-value> block after UpdateColor block and connect between UpdateColor and System blocks
Add another <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block with value 0.3 and connect to UpdateSize block's size input
Observe how particles now have consistent color and size throughout their lifetime

blocks.name: Update Color Block
blocks.description: Updates the color of particles each frame. In this lesson, we use it with a constant color value. In later lessons, we'll learn to change color over time.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: color
properties.description: The color to apply to the particle. Can be a constant Color4 value or a contextual value like InitialColor.

blocks.name: Update Size Block
blocks.description: Updates the size of particles each frame. In this lesson, we use it with a constant size value. In later lessons, we'll learn to change size over time.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size value to apply. Can be a constant value or calculated using math operations.

blocks.name: Input Block (Initial Color)
blocks.description: Retrieves the initial color of a particle when it was created. This is a contextual value that remembers the color from Create Particle block. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its contextual value to Initial Color in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Contextual Value
properties.description: The type of contextual data - Initial Color in this case. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Box Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a box volume. Used in this lesson to create particles from a visible box area. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

codeCopy: This lesson introduces Update Color and Update Size blocks. These blocks allow us to modify particle properties each frame. In this lesson, we use constant values - the color and size don't change over time. This is the foundation for more complex effects we'll learn in later lessons. The key concept is chaining update blocks: each block receives the particle from the previous block, modifies it, and passes it to the next block.
objectives: Learn to use Update Color and Update Size blocks
Understand how to chain multiple update blocks together
Use InitialColor contextual value to maintain particle color
Apply constant values to particle properties
Understand the update block chain: Update Position → Update Color → Update Size

commonMistakes.mistake: Chaining update blocks in wrong order
commonMistakes.explanation: Update blocks must be chained in a specific order. UpdatePosition should come first, then UpdateColor, then UpdateSize.
commonMistakes.solution: Chain blocks in order: Update Position → Update Color → Update Size → System. Connect each block's output to the next block's input by dragging connections in the editor.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong contextual value for color
commonMistakes.explanation: InitialColor retrieves the color set when the particle was created. Using Position or Direction will cause errors.
commonMistakes.solution: Use an Input block with Initial Color contextual value for Update Color block when you want to maintain the original particle color. Set this in the properties panel on the right.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not connecting update blocks to System block
commonMistakes.explanation: Update blocks must be connected to the System block, otherwise they won't be executed.
commonMistakes.solution: Always connect all update blocks to the System block. Drag the connection from the last update block's output to System block's particle input.

homework: Try different color values (red, blue, green, etc.)
Experiment with different size values (0.1, 0.5, 1.0, etc.)
Try using different emitter shapes (Box Shape, Cone Shape, etc.)
Combine different colors and sizes to see how they affect the visual appearance
